answers.author: Derek Johnson
answers.text:
Not in the current political gridlock, no. If the reaction to the Simpson/Bowles commission report proved anything, it's that any realistic road to solvency (take hikes, reducing social security and medicare benefits, cutting defense spending) will be blocked by whichever party considers them to be a sacred cow. Anything else, like the cliched "waste, fraud and abuse" and earmarks will just be nibbling at the edges of the problem.

answers.author: Susanne Scholz
answers.text:
I agree.  Recently I discovered that there truly is a push to place as many people as possible on social services.  I thought I was crazy, but the system and its employees (gov workers) are promoting this behavior and costing our states billions of dollars.   Why?  Why not promote resume building, obtaining a job, etc?  Then you have the VA who swipes the paperwork across their desk in an effort to earn a bonus without having actually performed their job.  The system is breaking and I for one am not certain how to fix it.  How do we MAKE our elected officials do their job morally, ethically, efficiently etc?

author: Kevin Carter
text:
Given the increased focus on reducing Federal spending, it looks like Federal agencies will start having to make the kind of cuts local governments have been making for the past 3 years. 
Any recommendations for Uncle Sam from those who have gone through budget cuts?
title: How to Cut Federal Spending
